reason: This PR was screwed up due me mistakenly pushing changes on the PR head.  I'm going to re-issue this.
description:
This PR is a replacement for @cosmosquark's [PR 1308](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-request/1308/wip-particle_cylindrical_r-and).  I did some big updates based on his work, and the discussion in that PR was starting to get really lengthy, so I've reissued the PR here.

This PR does two main things:

1.  The fields currently in yt with names like `particle_spherical_position_radius` return incorrect results.  See #966. This PR ensures these fields return correct results.

2. Adds new `particle_position_relative` and `particle_velocity_relative` fields.  This makes it possible to get particle positions and velocities in a rotated reference frame.

3. The naming system for particle vector fields has never been codified.  In this PR I implement a proposed naming system.  Particle vector fields will be of the form:

`particle_<vector field name>_coordinate`

The main advantage is that this matches our current naming system for cartesian coordinates (e.g. `particle_position_x`, `particle_velocity_y`.  So the spherical radius position field becomes `particle_position_spherical_radius`.

Where there are fields that are currently in yt that have names that do not match this naming convention, I've stubbed out their implementation and made them aliases for the fields with names following my proposed naming convention.  I've also marked these stub fields as deprecated in their docstrings.

When no field already existed (e.g. the position fields in cylindrical coordinates), I've simply added the new fields following my proposed naming convention without adding fields that would immediately need to be deprecated.

I'm confident that these are all giving correct results.  See this notebook: 

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ngoldbaum/e86250523d2ce2036669

Note that this notebook uses some work-in-progress machinery from [PR 1377](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-request/1377/wip-rfc-add-a-convenience-method-to-create).

I'm not sure whether this should go in before 3.1.  It's a significant change that includes some new code and fields, but it does correct some big issues with the spherical particle position fields.  I would very much appreciate comments on that front from PR reviewers.
title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: Sure, but this is just for the particle fields.  Haven't touched the index fields.
content.html: Sure, but this is just for the particle fields. Haven't touched the index fields.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw:
Your proposed naming scheme for particle fields has direct impacts for corresponding gas fields.

For example, by choosing to have particle fields as (as you do in this PR):

`particle_position_spherical_radius`

the equivalent gas field would be

`position_spherical_radius`

Whereas by choosing the particle fields to be (as was done previously, and suggested in the issue above):

`particle_spherical_position_radius`

the gas fields would be:

`spherical_position_radius`

Admittedly, both styles seem to be somewhat awkward constructions, but both gas fields and particle fields seemed to me to be slightly less awkward for the second set.  That said, I'm open to changing it, I just wanted everyone to realize the consequences this proposed change would have for other fields.
content.html:
Your proposed naming scheme for particle fields has direct impacts for corresponding gas fields.

For example, by choosing to have particle fields as (as you do in this PR):

particle_position_spherical_radius

the equivalent gas field would be

position_spherical_radius

Whereas by choosing the particle fields to be (as was done previously, and suggested in the issue above):

particle_spherical_position_radius

the gas fields would be:

spherical_position_radius

Admittedly, both styles seem to be somewhat awkward constructions, but both gas fields and particle fields seemed to me to be slightly less awkward for the second set. That said, I'm open to changing it, I just wanted everyone to realize the consequences this proposed change would have for other fields.

content.raw: Why do we need to change the gas fields?  Since they're `index` fields that indicates to me what they're positions already.
content.html: Why do we need to change the gas fields? Since they're index fields that indicates to me what they're positions already.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: While I'm using "position" as an example, I think this applies to "velocity" as well which are not `index` fields.
content.html: While I'm using "position" as an example, I think this applies to "velocity" as well which are not index fields.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw:
OK, then the field names would be of the form:

`('gas', 'velocity_spherical_radius')`

Which I think is preferable to 

`('gas', 'spherical_velocity_radius')`

for the same reasons I outlined in the PR description - mainly consistency with `('gas', 'velocity_x')`, but also it seems more natural to me.
content.html:
OK, then the field names would be of the form:

('gas', 'velocity_spherical_radius')

Which I think is preferable to

('gas', 'spherical_velocity_radius')

for the same reasons I outlined in the PR description - mainly consistency with ('gas', 'velocity_x'), but also it seems more natural to me.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: OK, so we disagree on the convention, which is fine, but I think other people should vote on the new proposed convention.  Ultimately, I don't care that much, but I just want consistency between the various parts of the code so we don't end up with inconsistent field naming as we've sometimes had in the past as the code grew organically.
content.html: OK, so we disagree on the convention, which is fine, but I think other people should vote on the new proposed convention. Ultimately, I don't care that much, but I just want consistency between the various parts of the code so we don't end up with inconsistent field naming as we've sometimes had in the past as the code grew organically.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw:
What would it take to get you to approve this?

I can:

* Update the gas velocity fields to match this naming convention

* Update the field naming YTEP

* Update the `index` position fields to match this naming convention (already done, I'd argue).
content.html:
What would it take to get you to approve this?

I can:

  • Update the gas velocity fields to match this naming convention

  • Update the field naming YTEP

  • Update the index position fields to match this naming convention (already done, I'd argue).

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw:
I agree that the gas field names should be updated for consistency. In my opinion I like the convention of

<particle?>_<vector_field_name>_<co-ordinate>

under this convention, would mean changing particle_relative_position to particle_position_relative?

Likewise for consistency, the gas fields would benefit from position_relative as well.

I am also for the idea of some sort of vote which @chummels has suggested. But I don't think it would be a good idea to spend days discussing a field convention... Pick something and stick with it.
content.html:
I agree that the gas field names should be updated for consistency. In my opinion I like the convention of

<particle?><vector_field_name><co-ordinate>

under this convention, would mean changing particle_relative_position to particle_position_relative?

Likewise for consistency, the gas fields would benefit from position_relative as well.

I am also for the idea of some sort of vote which Cameron Hummels has suggested. But I don't think it would be a good idea to spend days discussing a field convention... Pick something and stick with it.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: @ngoldbaum I *think* also cylindrical_r and spherical_r in the gas fields need to be replaced with cylindrical_radius and spherical_radius... But for the most parts, the rest does match this convention that we have.
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum I think also cylindrical_r and spherical_r in the gas fields need to be replaced with cylindrical_radius and spherical_radius... But for the most parts, the rest does match this convention that we have.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: Until we incorporate a `north_vector` field parameter which will make the choice of `particle_relative_position_x` and `particle_relative_position_y` non-arbitrary, could you include a note in the docstrings indicating that the orientation of this field is arbitrary?  Same for `particle_relative_position_y`, `particle_relative_position`.  It appears there is a short note in the `velocity` fields already.
content.html: Until we incorporate a north_vector field parameter which will make the choice of particle_relative_position_x and particle_relative_position_y non-arbitrary, could you include a note in the docstrings indicating that the orientation of this field is arbitrary? Same for particle_relative_position_y, particle_relative_position. It appears there is a short note in the velocity fields already.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: Should we deprecate the `particle_radius` field since we will now have `particle_spherical_position_radius` (or `particle_position_spherical_radius`)?  `particle_radius` sounds like the radius of individual particles.  Opinions?
content.html: Should we deprecate the particle_radius field since we will now have particle_spherical_position_radius (or particle_position_spherical_radius)? particle_radius sounds like the radius of individual particles. Opinions?

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: It is the radius of individual particles, and in fact it's exactly the same as `particle_position_spherical_radius`.  I'd prefer to leave it in since it's a useful alias.  I'm ok with having alias fields, so long as there is a corresponding field that matches the naming convention.
content.html: It is the radius of individual particles, and in fact it's exactly the same as particle_position_spherical_radius. I'd prefer to leave it in since it's a useful alias. I'm ok with having alias fields, so long as there is a corresponding field that matches the naming convention.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: I just wanted to get feedback from the other devs on which is the best naming convention to use between the two proposed.  When there is general consensus, I am happy to approve this PR, since it adds new functionality, removes broken functionality, makes a consistent field naming scheme, and adds documentation.
content.html: I just wanted to get feedback from the other devs on which is the best naming convention to use between the two proposed. When there is general consensus, I am happy to approve this PR, since it adds new functionality, removes broken functionality, makes a consistent field naming scheme, and adds documentation.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: IIRC, the particle_radius method returns radial distance from the centre of the cell this particle resides in? Which seems unnecessary if there is already a way to retrieve the host cell id.
content.html: IIRC, the particle_radius method returns radial distance from the centre of the cell this particle resides in? Which seems unnecessary if there is already a way to retrieve the host cell id.

pullrequest.title: Particle position and velocity fields for cylindrical and spherical coordinates

content.raw: That's fair.  I just thought the name suggested the intrinsic size of individual particles as opposed to their distance from the `center` field parameter.  But if we want to leave it, I'm not too aversed--I just thought it might be confusing.
content.html: That's fair. I just thought the name suggested the intrinsic size of individual particles as opposed to their distance from the center field parameter. But if we want to leave it, I'm not too aversed--I just thought it might be confusing.
